description.raw:
On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38154806/python-os-system-subprocess-do-not-recognize-microsofts-ie4uinit-exe) for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell __init__.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.
description.html:
On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See here for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell init.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.

title.raw: Fixes for installer to run with Python 3
title.html: Fixes for installer to run with Python 3

On a whim I decided to setup a Python 3 labscript environment just to be ready and ran the installation from scratch, finding a few bugs.

setup.py is already set up to run under python 2 or 3, but needs to alias raw_input to input for python 3.

Discovered an obtuse path quirk for the icon cache clearing when running 32-bit python on 64-bit windows. See here for details on why.

(not included in this pull request, obviously) labscript_utils.winshell init.py has a StringIO import that would need to be io.StringIO for python 3. However, the import isn't actually used and can be removed outright as far as I can tell.
